questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. An abdominal X-ray shows signs of bowel obstruction. Intraoperatively, the surgeon finds multiple fibrous bands with the cecum on the left side and the small intestine on the right side. What is the most likely underlying anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nonrotation of the midgut

 

Explanation:

Nonrotation of the midgut refers to a congenital anomaly where the midgut only completes the first 90° of the normal 270° counterclockwise rotation, leaving the midgut improperly positioned within the abdomen. This leads to abnormal positioning of the small intestine on the right and the colon on the left, predisposing the infant to volvulus and obstruction, as seen in this case. The bilious vomiting and abdominal distension are typical presentations of midgut volvulus.

 

Types of malrotation

 

Characteristic

Non-Rotation

Incomplete Rotation

Reverse Rotation

Features
  • Failure of normal 270° counterclockwise rotation.
  • Only the first 90° rotation occurs.
  • Small intestine is on the right side and large intestine on the left.

 
  • Incomplete rotation.
  • Large intestine passes behind the duodenum and the superior mesenteric artery (SMA).
  • SMA compresses the duodenum.
  • Intestines rotate 90° clockwise instead of counterclockwise.
  • Large intestine returns earlier and lies behind the duodenum and SMA.
  • Small intestine misplaced anteriorly.

Clinical Presentation
  • Abdominal distension
  • Bilious vomiting (if volvulus occurs)
  • Absent IC junction in RIF
  • IC junction may be midline, below the pylorus.
  • Bilious vomiting
  • Abdominal pain and distension
  • Features of duodenal obstruction (due to SMA compression).
  • Bilious vomiting
  • Failure to thrive
  • Symptoms of bowel obstruction
  • Possible shock if volvulus is present.

Complications
  • Volvulus
  • Intestinal obstruction

Surgical Management

Ladd’s procedure

Midgut volvulus with normal rotation (Option D): Midgut volvulus can still occur even with normal rotation, but it’s not the underlying cause here as the infant has abnormal rotation.

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting shortly after birth. X-ray abdomen is taken and is shown below. Further evaluation reveals pancreatic tissue encircling and compressing the second part of the duodenum. Which embryological structure is primarily responsible for this congenital abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Ventral pancreatic bud

 

Explanation:

Bilious vomiting, x-ray showing double bubble sign of duodenal obstruction and evaluation indicating presence of pancreatic tissue encircling and compressing the second part of the duodenum is suggestive of Annular pancreas, occurring due to abnormal rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud.

 

Development of pancreas:




 

Origin of Pancreatic Buds & its derivatives
  • Dorsal Pancreatic Bud: located in the dorsal mesentery, forms the upper part of the head, neck, body, and tail of the pancreas.
  • Ventral Pancreatic Bud: Arises near the hepatic bud in the ventral mesentery. Forms the lower part of the head and the uncinate process.

Rotation and Fusion:
  • Rotation of the duodenal loop brings the ventral pancreatic bud to the right side of the duodenum, eventually fusing with the dorsal bud.
  • Except for the tail, the pancreas becomes retroperitoneal after the fusion and rotation.

Duct System Formation
  • Main Pancreatic Duct (wirsung): Formed from the distal part of the dorsal duct and proximal part of the ventral duct.
  • Accessory Pancreatic Duct (santorini) : Derived from the proximal portion of the dorsal duct.

Papillae Openings
  • The main pancreatic duct opens into the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla with the bile duct.
  • The accessory duct opens at the minor duodenal papilla.

Exocrine and Endocrine Components
  • Exocrine Pancreas: Derived from endodermal cells that reorganize into acini.
  • Endocrine Pancreas: The islets of Langerhans develop from cells separating from the duct system.

Developmental anomalies of Pancreas

1. Annular pancreas:

  • The ventral pancreatic bud consists of two components that typically fuse and rotate around the duodenum, positioning below the dorsal bud. (Option B)
  • Sometimes, the right part migrates normally while the left moves in the opposite direction, leading to malformations that can constrict the 2nd part of the duodenum and cause obstruction.

2. Pancreatic divisum:



 
  • Failure of fusion of parts of pancreas derived from dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds with each other.
  • This leads to most pancreatic secretions draining through the accessory duct (duct of Santorini) into the minor papilla, which is often smaller and can become obstructed.
  • This incomplete drainage leads to recurrent pancreatitis.

Accessory pancreatic tissue

Accessory pancreatic tissue can be found in various locations, including:

  • Stomach wall
  • Duodenum (most common)
  • Meckel’s diverticulum
  • Greater omentum
  • Hilum of the spleen
 

It appears as yellowish, lobulated nodules, typically single and ranging from 1–6 mm in diameter. Approximately one-third of these nodules contain islets of Langerhans.

 

Dorsal pancreatic bud (Option A): Forms parts of the pancreas (body, neck, and tail), but does not encircle the duodenum and is not involved in annular pancreas formation.

 

Hepatic diverticulum (Option C): Develops into the liver and bile ducts, unrelated to pancreatic development or duodenal obstruction.

 

Vitelline duct (Option D): Related to the yolk sac and conditions like Meckel's diverticulum, not involved in pancreatic or duodenal development.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the peritoneal folds of abdomen?

choices.text: The greater omentum attaches to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the duodenum, providing a barrier to infections in the peritoneal cavity.
The lesser omentum connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm and provides support to the liver
The greater omentum forms a fold between the liver and the diaphragm, providing structural support to the stomach.
The greater omentum is often used as a free flap in reconstructive surgeries based on gastro-omental vessels in gastrointestinal perforations.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) The greater omentum is often used as a free flap in reconstructive surgeries based on gastro-omental vessels in gastrointestinal perforations.

 

Explanation :

The remarkable capacity of the greater omentum to participate in reparative processes is highlighted by its use as an omental pedicle flap or free flap in reconstructive surgery: it has been used to support closure of gastrointestinal perforations, fill ‘dead space’ after surgical excision of pathology, and cover wound defects.

 

Peritoneum:

The peritoneum consists of 2 layers: the superficial parietal layer and the deep visceral layer. The peritoneal cavity contains the omentum, ligaments, and mesentery.

 

  • The lesser omentum (or hepatogastric) is attached to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the liver.
  • The greater omentum (or gastrocolic) hangs from the greater curvature of the stomach and loops down in front of the intestines before curving back upwards to attach to the transverse colon.In effect it is draped in front of the intestines like an apron and may serve as an insulating or protective layer.

Omenta:

Sources

Structure

To

Contains

Dorsal mesentery

Greater omentum

Greater curvature of stomach (and spleen)

Transverse colon

right and left gastroepiploic vessels and fat

Gastrocolic ligament

Splenorenal ligament

Ventral mesentery

Liver

The right free margin-hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct,lymph nodes and the lymph vessels,hepatic plexus of nerve,all enclosed in perivascular fibrous sheath. Along the lesser curvature of the stomach-left and right gastric artery,the gastric group of lymph nodes and lymphatics, branches from the gastric nerve.

 

Hepatogastric ligament

Stomach

Liver

Hepatoduodenal ligament

Duodenum

Horizontal disposition of the peritoneum in the upper part of the abdomen

 

Horizontal disposition of the peritoneum in the lower part of the abdomen

 

Mesenteries

From

To

Contains

Dorsal mesentery

Mesentery proper

Small intestine (jejunum and ileum)

Posterior abdominal wall

Superior mesenteric artery, accompanying veins, autonomic nerve plexuses, lymphatics, 100–200 lymph nodes and connective tissue with fat

 

Transverse mesocolon

Transverse colon

Sigmoid colon

  • The greater omentum attaches to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the duodenum, providing a barrier to infections in the peritoneal cavity. (Option A): The greater omentum attaches to the greater curvature of the stomach, not the lesser curvature
  • The lesser omentum connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm and provides support to the liver (Option B) : The lesser omentum connects the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum to the liver (via the hepatic portal area), not the greater curvature or diaphragm.
  • The greater omentum forms a fold between the liver and the diaphragm, providing structural support to the stomach. (Option C) : The greater omentum does not connect the liver and diaphragm. The falciform ligament is a thin anteroposterior double fold of peritoneum that represents an anterior portion of the mesentery connecting the liver to the posterior aspect of the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text:
Match the following with their corresponding dermatomal distribution:


 


	
		
			
			
				Thumb
			
			
			
			1) L3
			
		
		
			
			
				Umblicus
			
			
			
			2) L5
			
		
		
			
			
				Knee
			
			
			
			3) C6
			
		
		
			
			
				Dorsum of foot
			
			
			
			4) T10
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

Explanation:


 

  1. Thumb

1) C6
  1. Umblicus

2) T10
  1. Knee

3) L3
  1. Dorsum of foot

4) L5

 

Dermatomes:

 

  • The sensory fibres in individual spinal and cranial nerves have characteristic, but often overlapping, peripheral (cutaneous) distributions.
  • As far as the innervation of the body surface is concerned, the area of skin that is supplied by a particular spinal or cranial nerve is referred to as a dermatome, and the areas of skin supplied by named peripheral nerves are often referred to as the peripheral nerve field (or cutaneous nerve distribution) of that nerve.

 

Nerve root

Dermatomal distribution

C2

Temple, Forehead, Occiput

C3

Entire Neck, Posterior Cheek, Temporal Area, Prolongation forward under Mandible

C4

Shoulder Area, Clavicular Area, Upper Scapular Area

C5

Deltoid Area, Anterior aspect of entire arm to base of thumb

C6

Anterior Arm, Radial side of hand to thumb and index finger

C7

Lateral Arm and Forearm to index, long, and ring fingers

C8

Medial Arm and forearm to long, ring, and little fingers

T1

Medial side of forearm to base of little finger

T2

Medial side of upper arm to medial elbow, pectoral and midscapular areas

T3-6

Upper Thorax

T5-7

Costal Margin

T8-12

Abdomen and Lumbar Region

L1

Back, over trochanter and groin

L2

Back, front of thigh to knee

L3

Back, upper buttock, anterior thigh and knee, medial lower leg

L4

Medial buttock, latera thigh, medial leg, dorsum of foot, big toe

L5

Buttock, posterior and lateral thigh, lateral aspect of leg, dorsum of foot, medial half of sole, first, second, and third toes

S1

Buttock, Thigh, and Leg Posterior

S2

Same as S1

S3

Groin, medial thigh to knee

S4

Perineum, genitals, lower sacrum

 

Clinical significance:

 

  • A dermatome is an area of skin supplied by sensory neurons that arise from a spinal nerve ganglion. Symptoms that follow a dermatome (e.g. like pain or a rash) may indicate a pathology that involves the related nerve root.

 

  • In referred pain, sensory nerve fibers such as that from dermatomes may come together at the same spinal cord level as the general visceral afferent fibers such as that from the heart. When the general visceral sensory fiber is stimulated, the central nervous system does not clearly discern whether the pain is coming from the body wall or from the viscera, so it perceives the pain as coming from somewhere on the body wall, e.g. left arm/hand pain, jaw pain. So the pain is "referred to" the related dermatomes of the same spinal segment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident and presents to the trauma unit with severe abdominal pain and hypotension. On examination, he has contusion on the left side of his abdomen. FAST reveals free fluid in the abdomen. CT scan shows a retroperitoneal hematoma and signs of injury to a retroperitoneal organ. Which of the following organs is most likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left Kidney

Explanation: A retroperitoneal hematoma seen on CT scan, along with the clinical signs of severe abdominal pain, contusion, and hypotension, strongly suggests that the left kidney has been injured in this case.

The retroperitoneum can occasionally be a site of significant bleeding, usually after trauma, surgical intervention, or even spontaneously in patients with vascular lesions (e.g., abdominal aortic aneurysm) or those treated with anticoagulation therapy.

Presentation varies based on etiology. Symptoms can include hypotension, tachycardia, ecchymoses in the affected areas, fatigue, hematuria, and flank or back pain. Computed tomography of the abdomen is the diagnostic imaging of choice.

Management of retroperitoneal hematoma is almost always medical, with resuscitation, blood transfusions, and reversal of anticoagulation as necessary.

Retroperitoneal Space:

The retroperitoneum is an anatomical space located behind the abdominal or peritoneal cavity. Abdominal organs that are not suspended by the mesentery and lie between the abdominal wall and parietal peritoneum are said to lie within the retroperitoneum.

Several individual spaces make up the retroperitoneum.

These spaces are the anterior pararenal space, posterior pararenal space, and the perirenal space.

The retroperitoneum divides into three main anatomical spaces:

  • The anterior pararenal space: contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).
  • The perirenal space: includes the adrenal gland, kidney, ureters, and renal vessels.
  • The posterior pararenal space: It is surrounded by the posterior leaf of the renal fascia and muscles of the posterior abdominal wall, contains no major organs and is composed primarily of fat, blood vessels, and lymphatics.
  • There is also a fourth, less well-defined space known as the great vessel space. It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and psoas muscles and contains the aorta, inferior vena cava, and surrounding fat.

 

  • The Stomach (Option A) is an intraperitoneal organ. Trauma to the stomach would generally present with signs of peritoneal irritation and perforation, not retroperitoneal bleeding.

 

  • The Small intestine (Option C) is also an intraperitoneal organ. Injury to the small intestine would typically cause signs of peritonitis, but not a retroperitoneal hematoma.

 

  • The Spleen (Option D) is an intraperitoneal organ located in the left upper quadrant. Injury to the spleen would more commonly present with signs of intraperitoneal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following planes carries the origin of the hepatic portal vein and the termination of the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Transpyloric plane

 

Explanation:

The origin of the hepatic portal vein and the termination of the spinal cord are in the transpyloric plane of the abdomen.

Quadrants of the abdomen

  • The abdomen is divided into 4 quadrants by a horizontal transumbilical plane and a vertical median plane. They are:
    • Right upper quadrant
    • Left upper quadrant
    • Right lower quadrant
    • Left lower quadrant

 

 

Vertical Planes

 

  • Midline (Median Plane): Passes through the xiphoid process and pubic symphysis.
  • Paramedian Lines: Left and right lines from midclavicular points to midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

Horizontal Planes

  • Xiphisternal Plane: Aligned with the T9 vertebral body; it often intersects the xiphisternal joint.
  • Transpyloric Plane: Midway between the jugular notch and the superior pubic symphysis; intersects the L1-L2 intervertebral disc or superior half of L2. Key structures include:
    • Superior mesenteric artery origin
    • Hepatic portal vein origin
    • Hilum of the left kidney
    • Renal arteries
    • Duodenojejunal flexure
    • Termination of the spinal cord (conus medullaris)
  • Subcostal Plane (Option A ruled out): Joins the lowest points of the costal arch; typically intersects the vertebral body of L2.
  • Supracristal Plane (Tuffier’s Line) (Option B ruled out): Joins the superior points of the iliac crests; corresponds to the aortic bifurcation (L4-L5).
  • Intertubercular Plane (Option C ruled out): Joins iliac tubercles; commonly at the L5 vertebral body.
  • Plane of the Pubic Crest: In line with the superior pubic symphysis; intersects the head of the femur and coccyx in supine individuals.

 

Nine regions of the abdomen

  • They are formed by the subcostal and intertubercular planes and left and right midclavicular lines.
  • The regions and their associated contents are:

 

Region

Contents

Right hypochondrium
  • Liver
  • Gallbladder

Epigastric region
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Duodenum

Left hypochondrium
  • Spleen
  • Left colic flexure

Right lumbar region
  • Right kidney
  • Right ureter
  • Ascending colon

Umbilical region
  • Loops of small intestine
  • Aorta
  • Inferior vena cava

Left lumbar region
  • Left kidney
  • Left ureter
  • Descending colon

Right iliac region
  • Caecum
  • Appendix

Hypogastric region
  • Coils of small intestine
  • Urinary bladder (if distended)
  • Uterus (if enlarged)

Left iliac region
  • Sigmoid colon

questions.text: A triangular area formed in the bladder is called the trigone. Which of the following is the origin of the epithelium of the trigone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mesonephric duct

 

Explanation:
The epithelium of the trigone is from the endothelium of absorbed mesonephric ducts.

Development of the Urinary Bladder: A Step-by-Step Process

Formation of the Cloaca

  • Cloaca: The terminal portion of the hindgut in the embryo.
  • Urorectal Septum: a partition that divides the cloaca into:
    • Dorsal Part: forms the primitive rectum, the later part of the large intestine.
    • Ventral Part: becomes the primitive urogenital sinus

Subdivisions of the Primitive Urogenital Sinus

  • Cranial Part (Upper): Forms the vesicourethral canal, a precursor to the urinary bladder and urethra.
  • Caudal Part (Lower): Develops into the definitive urogenital sinus, contributing to structures in both males and females.

 

Development of the Vesicourethral Canal

  • Regions of the Canal:
    • Wider Upper Part: Expands to become the urinary bladder.
    • Narrower Lower Part: Develops into the primitive urethra.

Incorporation of the Mesonephric Ducts

  • Mesonephric Ducts: Gradually absorbed into the posterior wall of the vesicourethral canal.
  • Trigone Formation: Absorbed portions contribute to the formation of the trigone, a triangular area in the bladder wall.

Fate of the Allantois

  • Allantois (Option D): Initially extends from the bladder apex and atrophies to form the urachus (median umbilical ligament), connecting the bladder to the umbilicus.

Cellular Origins and Layers

  • Epithelium: The inner lining originates from the endoderm of the cranial vesicourethral canal (Option A); trigone epithelium derives from the mesoderm of the absorbed mesonephric ducts.
  • Muscular and Serous Walls: Develop from splanchnic mesoderm (Option C) surrounding the developing gut.

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have hydronephrosis. Which of the following would be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aberrant renal arteries

Explanation:
Aberrant renal arteries cause compression of the ureters and cause hydronephrosis.
 

Ascent of Kidneys:
Early Development and Position

  • Metanephros: The definitive human kidney arises from the metanephros, initially located in the sacral region of the embryo.
  • Blood Supply: Receives blood from the lateral sacral arteries at this stage.

 

Ascent Process

  • Differential Growth:
    • As the embryo develops, significant growth of the abdominal wall causes the kidneys to ascend towards the lumbar region.
    • This ascent results from surrounding structures changing positions, not physical movement of the kidneys.
  • Change in Blood Supply:
    • Ascent leads to a shift in blood supply from lateral sacral arteries to higher branches of the aorta.
    • The definitive renal artery originates from the aorta at the second lumbar segment.

 

Factors Influencing Ascent

  • Abdominal Wall Growth: The primary driver of kidney ascent.
  • Umbilical Arteries:
    • During ascent, kidneys pass between the right and left umbilical arteries.
    • Obstruction by these arteries can impede ascent, causing kidneys to remain in the pelvic region. (Option A)

Rotation of the Kidney

  • Hilum Reorientation:
    • Initially, the hilum faces anteriorly; as the kidney ascends, it rotates to face medially (towards the midline).

Clinical Significance of Anomalies

  • Anomalies of Position:
    • Pelvic Kidney: Kidney remains in the sacral region.
    • Incomplete Ascent: Kidney lies opposite the lower lumbar vertebrae.
    • Thoracic Kidney: Rare ascent into the thoracic cavity.
    • Crossed Ectopia (Option B): Both kidneys are located on the same side of the midline.
  • Aberrant Renal Arteries:
    • Abnormal kidney position can lead to unusual blood supply, potentially compressing the ureter and causing hydronephrosis (kidney swelling due to urine buildup).
  • Malrotation (Option C)
    • Abnormal hilum position due to incomplete rotation

questions.text: A newborn presents with a congenital urinary tract anomaly. During evaluation, the physician explains the stages of kidney development and associated structures. Which of the following statements is true regarding the formation of the definitive kidney in mammals?

choices.text: Pronephros is the functional kidney in humans and contributes to the urinary system.
Mesonephros develops in the cervical region and contains excretory tubules.
Metanephros arises from the metanephric blastema and the ureteric bud.
Lateral plate mesoderm forms the foundation of the urinary and genital systems.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metanephros arises from the metanephric blastema and the ureteric bud.

 

Explanation:

Metanephros is the definitive kidney that arises from both the metanephric blastema (forming nephrons) and the ureteric bud (forming the collecting system).
 

Key Players in Development

  • Intermediate Mesoderm: Forms the foundation of the urinary and genital systems.(Option D)
  • Cloaca: Part of the hindgut; divides into the rectum and urogenital sinus.
  • Urogenital Ridge: Develops from the intermediate mesoderm, giving rise to the genital ridge (gonads) and nephrogenic cord (future kidneys).

 

Stages of Kidney Evolution

  • Pronephros (Most Primitive):
    • Develops in the cervical region of the nephrogenic cord.
    • Nonfunctional in humans; associated duct persists as the mesonephric duct.(Option A)
  • Mesonephros (Intermediate):
    • Functional in amphibians; develops in the thoracolumbar region.(Option B)
    • Consists of excretory tubules draining into the mesonephric duct; some tubules contribute to the male reproductive system.
  • Metanephros (Definitive Kidney):(Option C)
    • Functional kidney in mammals, birds, and reptiles; begins in the sacral region.
    • Arises from two sources:
      1. Excretory Tubules (Nephrons): Develop from the metanephric blastema.
      2. Collecting System: Forms from the ureteric bud branching from the mesonephric duct.

Step-by-Step Formation of the Kidney

  • Ureteric Bud Branching:
    • The ureteric bud grows towards metanephric blastema, forming an ampulla.
    • Ampulla divides to form the renal pelvis, major and minor calyces, and collecting tubules.
  • Nephron Formation:
    • Ampulla induces differentiation in the metanephric blastema, leading to nephron formation.
    • Cells form vesicles, elongate into S-shaped tubules, and develop glomeruli through capillary invasion.

Ascent and Rotation of the Kidney

  • Ascent:
    • Initially located in the sacral region it ascends to the lumbar region as the abdominal wall grows.
    • Acquires new blood supply from higher aortic branches.
  • Rotation:
    • Hilum faces anteriorly at first; and rotates medially during ascent.

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Imaging reveals malrotation of the midgut. The pediatric surgeon explains that during normal embryological development, the midgut should rotate around a specific arterial axis to reach its anatomical position. How many degrees does the midgut rotate, and what is the axis of this rotation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 270 degrees, Superior Mesenteric Artery

Explanation:

 

During normal embryological development, the midgut undergoes a rotation of 270 degrees counterclockwise around the axis of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). This rotation helps position the intestines correctly within the abdominal cavity. If this rotation does not occur properly, it can lead to malrotation.

 

The midgut loop undergoes a counterclockwise rotation (approximately 270 degrees) around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). This rotation occurs in two phases:

  • Initial 90-degree Rotation: As the loop begins to retract from the umbilical cord, it rotates 90 degrees counterclockwise.
  • Final 180-degree Rotation: Once retracted fully into the abdominal cavity, it completes an additional 180-degree rotation.

Final Positioning:

  • After the complete rotation, the small intestine is positioned predominantly in the upper left quadrant, while the colon occupies the right side of the abdomen.
  • The duodenum becomes fixed to the posterior abdominal wall, which is important for its stability and function.

 

Formation of Mesenteries:

The rotation and positioning of the intestines also result in the development of mesenteries, which are double layers of peritoneum that support the intestines and provide blood supply and nerve connections.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of recurrent abortion undergoes an ultrasound at 8 weeks of gestation and is found to have an abnormality in the fetus as shown below (arrow). The doctor reassures her that this condition typically resolves on its own. When should she schedule a follow-up ultrasound to monitor the resolution of the abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12 weeks

Explanation:

Ultrasound shows physiological umbilical hernia.

A physiological umbilical hernia is a normal developmental process where the intestines temporarily protrude into the base of the umbilical cord during early pregnancy. This occurs as the fetal abdomen is too small to accommodate the rapidly growing intestines. By around 12 weeks of gestation, the intestines typically return to the abdominal cavity, and the umbilical hernia resolves on its own. A follow-up ultrasound around 12 weeks is recommended to ensure proper closure and development.

 

Physiological Umbilical Hernia (PUH):

 

Occurs during early embryogenesis due to rapid growth of the midgut and liver, temporarily exceeding the size of the abdominal cavity.

 

  • Midgut Herniation (6th Week): The midgut herniates into the umbilical cord as the abdominal cavity is too small. It undergoes a 90-degree counterclockwise rotation around the superior mesenteric artery.
  • Midgut Retraction (10th-12th Week): The abdominal cavity expands, allowing the midgut to return. During retraction, an additional 180-degree counterclockwise rotation completes the 270-degree total, positioning the intestines.

 

Failure to Regress: Omphalocele: If the midgut doesn't return, omphalocele occurs, where organs remain herniated through the umbilical ring, covered by a membrane. It differs from Gastroschisis, where the organs protrude without a membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the ligament of Treitz is not true?

choices.text: It connects the duodenojejunal flexure to the right crus of the diaphragm.
It contains striated muscle fibers in its upper part.
It primarily serves as a conduit for blood supply to the small intestine.
It acts as a landmark in the diagnosis of intestinal malrotation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It primarily serves as a conduit for blood supply to the small intestine.


Explanation:

The ligament of Treitz does not serve as a conduit for blood supply to the small intestine; it is done by the superior mesenteric arteries. The ligament primarily stabilizes the duodenojejunal flexure and serves as an anatomical landmark.

 

Retention bands are ligaments that hold the gut in place during the primitive gut loop and rotation phase

There are 2 types of retention band

  • Superior retention band: Develops into ligament of Treitz.
  • Inferior retention band: Undergoes atrophy.

 

Ligament of Treitz

It is a fibromuscular band that suspends the duodenojejunal flexure from the right crus of the diaphragm. (Option A)

 

Attachments:

  • Upper end connects to the right crus of the diaphragm.
  • Lower end attaches to the posterior surface of the duodenojejunal flexure.

Composition:

  • Striated muscle fibers in the upper part. (Option B)
  • Elastic fibers in the middle.
  • Non-striated muscle fibers in the lower part.

Function:

  • Fixes the duodenojejunal flexure in place.
  • Prevents downward displacement by the weight of the small intestine.

 

Clinical Relevance: Acts as an important landmark in radiological assessments for diagnosing incomplete rotation or malrotation of the small intestine.(Option D)

questions.text: A healthcare provider is discussing the anatomy of the umbilical cord with a medical student. How many arteries and veins are typically present in a normal umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 arteries and 1 vein

 

Explanation:

Umbilical cord has one umbilical vein and two umbilical arteries.

 

Contents of the Umbilical Cord

Umbilical Arteries

Two arteries transport deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

Umbilical Vein

Initially, two veins are present; The right one disappears.

The remaining left umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

Wharton's Jelly

A gelatinous substance derived from the mucoid degeneration of the mesoderm of the connecting stalk protects umbilical vessels.

Allantoic Diverticulum

Ventral projection of hindgut into the connecting stalk.

It is incorporated into the urinary bladder proximally and forms the urachus distally.

Vitellointestinal Duct

Connection between the midgut and yolk sac; usually disappears but may leave remnants like cysts or fibrous cords.

Intra and Extraembryonic Coelom Communication

Exists at the fetal end around the vitellointestinal duct until week 10, allowing for a physiological hernia of the midgut loop.

 

 

Umbilical Cord Development:

 

  • Origin
    • Develops from the yolk sac and carries its remnants as contents.
    • The umbilical cord develops from the connecting stalk, a tubular structure covered by the amniotic membrane.
  • Week 2
    • The appearance of extraembryonic coelom divides extraembryonic mesoderm into two layers, leaving one area.
    • An unsplit mesoderm forms the connecting stalk, suspending the embryonic disc, amniotic cavity, and yolk sac.
  • Week 3
    • Allantoic diverticulum, an outpouching of the secondary yolk sac, extends into the connecting stalk's mesoderm.
    • Development of extraembryonic blood vessels in the connecting stalk and chorion forms umbilical vessels.
  • Week 4
    • Embryonic folding repositions the connecting stalk and the allantoic diverticulum to the ventral surface of the embryo.
    • The yolk sac turns into the head and tail folds, giving rise to the foregut and hindgut with the midgut in between.
    • The communication between the midgut and definitive yolk sac (extraembryonic part) is the vitellointestinal duct.
    • The amniotic membrane encases these structures, forming the umbilical cord.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the development of the liver and gallbladder is correct?

choices.text: Liver develops from the mesodermal hepatic bud.
Cystic duct forms from the pars hepatica of the hepatic bud.
Bile duct initially opens on the dorsal aspect of the developing duodenum.
Vitelline and umbilical veins contribute to the formation of hepatic sinusoids.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vitelline and umbilical veins contribute to the formation of hepatic sinusoids.

 

Explanation: Vitelline and umbilical veins within septum transversum get absorbed and broken to form hepatic sinusoids.

 

Development of Liver:

  • Develops from the endodermal hepatic bud.(Option A)
  • Hepatic bud arises as an outgrowth from the ventral margin of the terminal part of the foregut.
  • Hepatic bud grows ventrally and cranially into the ventral mesogastrium and through it into the septum transversum.
  • Hepatic bud elongates and divides into:
    • Pars hepatica: Forms the liver.
    • Pars cystica: Forms the gallbladder and cystic duct.(Option B)
  • Division of Pars Hepatica:
    • Divides into right and left branches to form right and left hepatic ducts.
    • Two termination of hepatic ducts forms: Right and left lobes of the liver.
  • Formation of Hepatic Architecture:
    • Hepatic bud (endoderm) forms:
      • Hepatic cells
      • Intrahepatic biliary apparatus (parenchyma).
    • Vitelline and umbilical veins within septum transversum get absorbed and broken to form hepatic sinusoids. (Option C)
    • Septum transversum (intraembryonic mesoderm) contributes to:
      • Fibrous capsule of Glisson
      • Kupffer’s cells
      • Hematopoietic cells
      • Connective tissue cells
      • Blood vessels
    • Absorption and breakdown of vitelline and umbilical veins in septum tranversum forms: Sinusoids

Development of Gallbladder:

  • Gallbladder and cystic duct develop from the pars cystica of the hepatic bud.
  • Common bile duct forms from the narrow section of the hepatic bud between the pars cystica and the duodenum.
  • Initially, the bile duct opens on the ventral aspect of the developing duodenum. (Option C)
  • Due to differential growth and rotation of the duodenal loop, the bile duct shifts to open on the dorsomedial aspect, alongside the ventral pancreatic bud.

questions.text: A research study is conducted to understand the embryological development of gastrointestinal (GI) structures in an embryo. Which of the following statements about the normal embryological development of the GI tract is incorrect?

choices.text: Esophagus develops entirely from the foregut.
Stomach initially forms as a fusiform dilation of the foregut.
Duodenum forms a C-shaped loop during stomach rotation.
Midgut-derived parts of the duodenum are supplied by the celiac artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Midgut-derived parts of the duodenum are supplied by the celiac artery.

 

Explanation: Midgut-derived parts of the duodenum are actually supplied by the superior mesenteric artery, not the celiac artery.

 

Development of Esophagus:

  • Develops from the foregut part between the pharynx and the stomach.(Option A)
  • Initially short, it elongates with neck development, diaphragm descent, and pleural cavity expansion.
  • Muscular coat of the esophagus is derived from the surrounding visceral mesenchyme.
  • Upper two-thirds of the esophagus contains striated muscle, innervated by the vagus nerve.
  • Lower one-third of the esophagus contains smooth muscle, innervated by the splanchnic plexus.

 

Development of Stomach:

  • Begins as a fusiform dilatation of the foregut, distal to the esophagus.(Option B)
  • Dorsally attached to the posterior abdominal wall by the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • Ventrally attached to the septum transversum by the ventral mesogastrium.
  • Stomach Rotation:
    • First rotation: 90॰clockwise along the longitudinal axis, reorienting the stomach's surfaces and shifting the position of the vagus nerves.
    • Second rotation: Along the anteroposterior axis, altering the position of the fundus, duodenum, and ends of the stomach.

Development of Duodenum:

  • Duodenum above the entry of the bile duct (first part and upper half of the second part) is derived from the foregut.
  • Part below the entry of the bile duct (remaining portion of second part along with third and fourth part) is derived from the midgut.

  • Rotation of stomach: Duodenum forms a C-shaped loop and rotates to the right.(Option C)
  • Developing duodenum is initially attached to the posterior abdominal wall by the mesoduodenum, which later fuses with the peritoneum, making most of the duodenum retroperitoneal.
  • Blood Supply of Duodenum:
    • Foregut derived parts: Celiac artery
    • Midgut derived parts: Superior mesenteric artery (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the development of mesentery is correct?

choices.text: Dorsal mesentery is derived from the septum transversum.
Ventral mesentery gives rise to the greater omentum.
Dorsal mesentery extends from the lower esophagus to the rectum.
Ventral mesentery is continuous with the dorsal mesentery.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dorsal mesentery extends from the lower esophagus to the rectum.

 

Explanation: Dorsal Mesentery is a collection of connective tissue that maintains the gut tube; it extends from the lower esophagus to the rectum,

 

Mesentery:

  • Initially, the foregut, midgut, and hindgut are in contact with the mesenchyme of the posterior abdominal wall.
  • By the fifth week of development, the gut is suspended by the dorsal mesentery from the abdominal wall.

  • Dorsal Mesentery:
    • Collection of connective tissue that maintains the gut tube and its derivatives in anatomical position.
    • It extends from the lower esophagus to the rectum, acting as a pathway for blood vessels, lymphatics and nerves to the gut tubes and their derivatives. (Option C)
    • Its name varies based on the gut tube segment it attaches to:
      • Dorsal mesogastrium
      • Greater omentum (Option B)
      • Mesoduodenum
      • Mesentery proper (small intestine)
      • Mesocolon
      • Mesoappendix
      • Mesosigmoid
      • Mesorectum
  • Ventral Mesentery:
    • Derived from the septum transversum.(Option A)
    • Growth of liver into septum divides it into:
      • Ventral mesogastrium (lesser omentum): Extending from the stomach and most parts of the duodenum to the liver.
      • Falciform ligament: Extending from the liver to the ventral body wall.
    • Ventral mesentery is not continuous with the dorsal mesentery. (Option D)

 

  • Derivatives of Ventral and Dorsal Mesogastrium:

 

 

Peritoneum:

 

  • Continuous serous membrane lining the inner surface of the abdominal cavity.
  • It reflects onto the viscera (internal organs).
  • Visceral peritoneum: Layer in direct contact with the viscera (organs).
  • Parietal peritoneum: Layer attached to the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal Reflections: Occur where the peritoneum bridges the space between an organ and the posterior abdominal wall.
    E.g.: Coronary and triangular reflections: Found on the surface of the liver;
    Lienorenal reflection: Connects the spleen and the left kidney.

 

Blood Supply in Primitive Gut:

  • During the formation of the primitive gut, the dorsal aorta gives off ventral branches to the gut.
  • Branches in the region of the midgut extend to the yolk sac and are called vitelline arteries.
  • Most of the ventral branches of the dorsal aorta disappear over time, except for three major arteries:
    • Celiac artery: Supplies the foregut
    • Superior mesenteric artery: Supplies the midgut
    • Inferior mesenteric artery: Supplies the hindgut

questions.text: A patient on examination and radiological imaging was found to have an absent gallbladder. Which gut tube structure is associated with this defect, and what is the primitive artery that supplies it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foregut, celiac trunk

 

Explanation:

 

  • The gallbladder is derived from the foregut.
  • The gallbladder develops as an outpouching from the hepatic diverticulum of the foregut during embryonic development. The foregut is primarily supplied by the celiac trunk, a major branch of the abdominal aorta.

 

Gut Tube:

 

The gut tube is a primitive structure that forms during early embryonic development and eventually gives rise to the organs of the digestive system and associated structures.

  • It is derived from the endoderm, one of the three primary germ layers, and extends from the future mouth (oropharyngeal membrane) to the anus (cloacal membrane).
  • The gut tube is typically divided into three main regions.



 

Foregut

Midgut

Hindgut

Extends from: Oropharyngeal membrane to the first part of the duodenum (distal to the bile duct)

Extends from: Distal part of the duodenum (after the bile duct entrance) to the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon

Extends from: Distal third of the transverse colon to the cloacal membrane

Derivatives:

  • Pharynx
  • Esophagus
  • Stomach
  • Proximal half of the duodenum (up to the bile duct)
  • Liver
  • Gallbladder
  • Pancreas
  • Respiratory system

Derivatives:

  • Distal half of the duodenum
  • Jejunum
  • Ileum
  • Cecum and appendix
  • Ascending colon
  • Proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon

Derivatives:

  • Distal third of the transverse colon
  • Descending colon
  • Sigmoid colon
  • Rectum
  • Upper anal canal (above pectinate line)
  • Urinary bladder and urethra (urogenital sinus)

Arterial supply: Celiac trunk

Arterial supply: Superior mesenteric artery

Arterial supply: Inferior mesenteric artery

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is brought to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress. The physical examination reveals scaphoid abdomen, decreased breath sounds on the left side, and a chest X-ray shows a mediastinal shift to the right. Which type of hernia is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bochdalek hernia

 

Explanation:

Given the age of the infant and the clinical presentation of severe respiratory distress, decreased breath sounds, and mediastinal shift, the most likely diagnosis is a Bochdalek hernia. It directly leads to lung compression and impaired respiratory function.

 

Bochdalek hernia

Morgagni hernia

More common congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)

Less common CDH

Often left sided

Often right sided

M/c site: Postero lateral

M/c side: Anteromedial (retrosternal)

Spleen and intestines enter the thoracic cavity.

The transverse colon enters the thoracic cavity.

Intestine passes through the left pleuroperitoneal membrane and makes the left lung small.

The transverse colon passes through the right retrosternal space (space of Morgagni) behind the sternum but in front of the heart.

questions.text: What structures are transmitted through the marked opening of the diaphragm in the given image?

choices.text: Inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve
Inferior vena cava and left phrenic nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve

 

Explanation:

The marked opening in the above image is vena caval hiatus which contains inferior vena cava and right phrenic nerve.

Major openings in the diaphragm

 

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Location

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through the opening
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right phrenic nerve (Option C)(Option D)
  • Oesophagus (Option A)
  • Right and left vagus nerve
  • Aorta (Option B)
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

(Mnemonic: VOA (Voice Of America))

 

Small openings in the diaphragm

  • Larry’s Space (Foramen of Morgagni) - Superior epigastric vessels pass between diaphragm origins at xiphoid process and 7th costal cartilage.
  • Median arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels
  • Splanchnic nerve passes through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.
  • The azygous vein may pass through the left crus.

questions.text: All of the following are the derivatives of the structure labeled A in the image below, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ligamentum teres

 

Explanation: Structure labeled A is septum transversum.

Ligamentum teres (round ligament of the liver) is not derived from the septum transversum. It is a remnant of the left umbilical vein.

 

Septum Transversum:

 

The septum transversum is an embryological structure that plays a vital role in early development, serving as a partial barrier between the thoracic and abdominal cavities. It contributes to the formation of several structures

 

Location and Function

  • Initial Position: The septum transversum forms between the developing heart and liver, creating a partition between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

  • Early Role: In early embryonic development, it functions as a partial diaphragm, separating the coelomic cavity into the thoracic (above) and abdominal (below) compartments. This separation is not complete, as gaps remain, which are later closed by other structures.

 

Derivatives of the Septum Transversum

1. Central Tendon of Diaphragm (Diaphragm) 

2.Portions of Liver Mesenchyme (Liver):

  • Connective tissue stroma of the liver including Glisson’s capsule (fibrous capsule of the liver).
  • Peritoneal coverings of liver
  • Kupffer cells, Hemopoietic cells, sinusoids, etc

3. Ventral mesentery of the foregut.
Derivatives of Ventral mesentery: Falciform ligament, Lesser omentum, Coronary ligament. (Options A, B and D)

4. Fibrous pericardium

 

Associated Membranes and Cavities:

  • The septum transversum is sometimes referred to as the pericardioperitoneal membrane, as it separates the developing pericardial cavity (containing the heart) from the peritoneal cavity (containing abdominal organs like the liver and stomach).
  • It also contributes to the separation of the right and left pleuroperitoneal membranes, which are involved in the development of the pleural cavities surrounding the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following structures contributes to the formation of the marked part of the diaphragm (inferior view)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dorsal mesentery of esophagus

 

Explanation:

The marked part of the diaphragm corresponds to the crura of the diaphragm, which is primarily derived from the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus.

 

Part of Diaphragm

Source of Development

1. Central Tendon of Diaphragm

Septum transversum

2. Small Peripheral Part

Pleuroperitoneal Membrane

3. Crura of Diaphragm

Dorsal Mesentery of Esophagus

4. Large Peripheral Part

Mesoderm of Body Wall

questions.text: Which of the following is true about gastroschisis as opposed to an omphalocele?

choices.text: Has a covering of amnion around the herniated bowels
Is associated with chromosomal anomalies and cardiac anomalies
Due to the failure of the gut tube back to return into the abdomen
The herniated bowel loops are damaged due to amniotic fluid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The herniated bowel loops are damaged due to amniotic fluid

 

Explanation:

The herniated loops of the bowel in gastroschisis are exposed as they lack any covering as in omphalocele and hence can be affected by the corrosive effect of amniotic fluid.


 

 

Gastroschisis

Omphalocele

Definition

A congenital defect where the abdominal wall fails to close, leading to herniation of intestinal loops into the amniotic cavity.

M/c in premature/SGA babies

A congenital ventral body wall defect where portions of the midgut fail to return to the abdominal cavity after physiological herniation.(Option C)

Location of defect

Right paraumbilical

Central

Sac

Absent, bowel is exposed.

Present (if not ruptured).

Sac is made of amnion, Wharton's jelly and peritoneum (Option A)

Description

Free intestinal loops.

(Liver is not usually herniated)

Firm mass including liver, intestine and/ other organs (like stomach, spleen)

Umbilical cord

Adjacent to the defect

Attached to the sac

Associated anomalies

Associated anatomic defects are uncommon

Associated abnormalities are common and include:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Cardiac abnormalities (Option B)
  • Chromosomal defect

Detection

  • Identified through fetal ultrasound.
  • Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in maternal serum and amniotic fluid.

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) concentrations in maternal serum and amniotic fluid, similar to gastroschisis.

Complication

  • Affected bowel loops may be damaged due to exposure to corrosive amniotic fluid.
  • Risk of volvulus, where the bowel twists around itself, compromising blood supply.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Failure to thrive
  • Inguinal hernias
  • Gastroesophageal reflux
  • Occasionally esophagitis

Prognosis

Favorable

High mortality rates

Image

                     Fig: Omphalocele

questions.text: A neonate presents with dribbling of urine from the umbilicus. Which of the following statements is true regarding the affected structure?

choices.text: Persistence of a small area of allantois
The lumen of the upper part of the urachus persists
Forms a cystic dilation due to secretions from the lining
Persistence of intraembryonic part of allantois

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Persistence of intraembryonic part of allantois

 

Explanation:

Dribbling of urine from the umbilicus is a finding in cases of urachal fistula. It is caused by the persistence of the intraembryonic portion of the allantois.

 

Urachus is formed by fibrosis of the distal part of the allantoic diverticulum. Its proximal part joins the apex of the urinary bladder.

 

Urachal anomalies lead to bladder defects like:

  • Urachal fistula
    • Caused by the persistence of the intraembryonic portion of allantois.
    • Causes urine to drain from the umbilicus.
       
  • Urachal cyst
    • When only a small area of the allantois persists. (Option A)
    • The secretory action from the lining results in a cystic dilation. (Option C)
       
  • Urachal sinus
    • When the lumen of the upper part persists and forms a sinus. (Option B)
    • Usually continuous with the urinary bladder.

questions.text: A newborn is scheduled for surgery after presenting with fecal discharge from the umbilicus. An intraoperative image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Vitelline fistula

 

Explanation: Newborn exhibiting fecal discharge from the umbilicus, along with intraoperative finding of vitelline duct joining umbilicus to small intestine point towards diagnosis of vitelline fistula or umbilical fistula.

 

Vitelline duct

  • The midgut during the early embryonic period communicates with the extraembryonic part of the yolk sac via the vitellointestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct.
  • It's involved in nutrient transfer and hematopoiesis
  • It disappears by the 5th week of development, and if it persists, it leads to the following anomalies:


 

Vitelline duct anomalies

Meckel’s diverticulum (Option A)

It is the persistent proximal part of the embryonic Vitello intestinal duct.

Key features:

  • It occurs in about 2% of the population.
  • Its length is around 2 inches (5 cm).
  • It is located 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal junction.
  • It is more common in males.
  • Its wall structure and caliber resemble that of the ileum. It is a true diverticulum containing all the layers of ileum.
  • The apex may be free or connected to the umbilicus by a fibrous band.
  • It attaches to the antimesenteric border of the ileum.
  • It can contain ectopic gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.
  • Generally asymptomatic, but it can cause:
    • Intestinal obstruction.
    • Ulceration and bleeding if ectopic gastric mucosa or pancreatic tissue is present, mimicking acute abdomen.
    • Symptoms resembling acute appendicitis when inflamed.

Vitelline fistula (Option B)
  • If the vitelline duct remains patent, it creates a direct connection between the umbilicus and the intestinal tract.
  • This condition is called an umbilical fistula or vitelline fistula.
  • It can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

Vitelline sinus (Option C)

If the distal segment of the vitelline duct remains patent, it can lead to the development of an umbilical sinus

Vitelline cyst (Option D)
  • When both ends of the vitelline duct become fibrous cords and the middle portion forms a large cyst, known as an enterocystoma or vitelline cyst.
  • Fibrous cords can cause intestinal obstruction, strangulation, or volvulus.
